coredata.dc:title: Inner valence levels as a structural probe For chemisorbed molecules: O2 on Pt(111)
coredata.dc:creator: Eberhardt, W.
Upton, T.
Cramm, S.
Incoccia, L.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We have measured the electronic structure of O2 chemisorbed in a π-bonded configuration on Pt(111) at 100 K. The positions of the inner valence levels of the adsorbate are extremely sensitive to the molecular adsorbate bond length. Comparing the measured binding energies of the three innermost σ-valence orbitals with calculations for the free O2 molecule, we deduce a bond length of 1.40±0.04 Å for the chemisorbed O2 species. This is substantially larger than the internuclear distance in the free molecule (1.21 Å). This study establishes that inner valence photoemission can be used to quantitatively determine the bond lengths for molecular adsorbates.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: 20 May 1988 Volume 146, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS INNER VALENCE LEVELS AS A STRUCTURAL PROBE FOR CHEMISORBED MOLECULES: 02 ON Pt(11I) W. EBERHARDT, T. UPTON Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Route 22 East, Annandale, NJ 08801, USA S. CRAMM Ii. institut fur Experimentalphysik, Universitat Hamburg, Lauruper Chaussee 149, D-2000 Hamburg 52, FederaiRepublic of Germany and L. INCOCCIA Hasylab DESY, Not kestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Federal Republic of Germany Received 9 February 1988; in final form 7 March 1988 We have measured the electronic structure 0102 chemisorbed in a n-bonded configuration on Pt (111) at 100 K. The positions of the inner valence levels of the adsorbatc are extremely sensitive to the molecular adsorbate bond length. Comparing the mea- sured binding energies of the three innermost a-valence orbitaIs with calculations for the free 02 molecule, we deduce a bond length of 1.40 0.04 A for the chemisorbed 0, species. This is substantially larger than the internuclear distance in the free molecule (1.21 A) - This study establishes that inner valence pholoemission can be used to quantitatively determine the bond lengths for molecular adsorbates. In a chemisorbed molecule the intramolecular bonding is modified due to the electronic interaction between the molecular orbitals and the surface. A de- tailed study of the electronic structure of the adsor- bate complex reveals which orbitals are involved in the chemisorption bond and which orbitals are just changed as a consequence of the interaction with the surface. Here we present a study where the complete determination of the valence orbitals of a molecular diatomic adsorbate is additionally used to deduce the changes in the molecular geometry. This extension of photoemission as a quantitative structural tool is possible since to first order the inner valence orbitals are not directly involved in the interaction with the substrate. Therefore, the energy splitting between the innermost a orbitals reflects directly the change in the intramolecular bonding and bond length of the molecule whereas the outer valence orbitals reflect the interaction with the Pt substrate. We have tested this concept by measuring the elec- tronic structure of 02 adsorbed onto Pt (ill) at low temperatures (~ 100 K). From the vibrational spec- trum, as determined by low-energy electron loss spectroscopy [1], and from NEXAFS [2] data it is known that oxygen adsorbs on this surface in mo- lecular form in a it-bonded configuration. The O O axis is parallel to the surface and the bond length is stretched by about 0.25 A [21, with respect to the isolated molecule largely due to charge transfer into the antibonding lltg molecular orbitals. The experiments were performed using the FLIP- PER monochromator at Hasylab Hamburg [3]. The electrons were detected by a commercial double-pass CMA electron energy analyzer. The crystal was cleaned by heating in oxygen followed by Ar ion bombardment and annealing. The surface cleanli- ness was checked initially by Auger spectroscopy and later largely by photoemission. The crystal was cooled o 009-2614/88/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers By. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 561 Volume 146, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 20 May 1988 to a temperature of approximately 100 K. After the initial cool-down period (30 mm), the crystal was flashed to about 400 C to remove any contaminants and exposed to 5 L 02 after it had reached the base temperature again, which took about 5 min. Fig. I shows the valence band photoemission of clean Pt (111) and after adsorption of 02 taken at a photon energy of 150 eV. This photon energy was chosen to be near the Cooper minimum of the Pt d- band emission in order to enhance the contribution of the adsorbate-induced states relative to the sub- strate emission. The top curve of fig. 1 shows the dif- ference between the adsorbate covered and the clean surface. The peaks at a binding energy of 21.2 and 11.8 eV are assigned to the 2o~ and 3; orbitals of the adsorbate, whereas the x orbitais are found in a broad band between 5 and 9 eV binding energy. The x orbitais are involved in the chemisorption bond with the substrate, which lifts the degeneracy be- tween the x and y components. The innermost 2; orbital does not show up with Fig. 1. Photoemission of clean Pt( 111) and after adsorption of 5 L 02 at 100 K taken at a photon energy of 150 eV. The difference curve is shown at the top. sufficient strength in the spectra taken at 150 eV photon energy. Therefore we studied the resonant photoemission (DES, deexcitation electron spec- troscopy) [4] at the O K edge and the results are shown in fig. 2. The electronic decay of the O is core to bound state excitation shows an enhancement of the single-hole final states, when compared to the normal O is Auger spectrum, which follows O is core ionization [4,5]. Both spectra are shown in fig. 2. In the DES spectrum features at kinetic energies of 518, 508.7 and 500.5 eV are enhanced. These fea- tures are assigned to the following single-hole con- figurations: 3; (518 eV), 2a~ (508.7 eV) and 2; (500.5 eV). Thus we have located the 2; orbital at a binding energy 8.2 eV larger than the 2a~ orbital. In making this assignment we are fully aware of the fact that in general the photoemission out of the innermost valence orbitals in molecules does not lead to single-hole final states. Quite a few different con- figurations are usually mixed into these final states [6]. However, in the isolated 02 molecule a peak at about 40 eV binding energy has a large 2; single-hole component and is assigned to this state [7,8]. This assignment is also supported by the relative en- 490 500 510 520 KIn~tIc Energy (eV) 530 Fig. 2. Auger spectrum and deexcitation spectrum (DES) of 02 on Pt( 111). The DES spectrum, which is generated in the elec- tronic decay opf the 0 ls core to bound state resonance excita- tion, shows an enhancement of the single.hole final-state configurations. Pt (111) + 0~ DES hu = 535 eV ~ Sp ~ AES ~. hv=545eV Binding Energy (eV) 562 Volume 146, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS 20 May 1988 hancement of the cross section of this peak in chang- ing the excitation energy from 100 eV [9] to 1156 eV (MgKct) [7]. The measured single-particle binding energies are listed in table 1 for 02 on Pt (111), 02 physisorbed on graphite [9], and gas phase 02 [7,8]. We used the 2a5 2a~ splitting measured in DES, rather than the absolute binding energies, in the determination of the position of the 2; orbital. Thus the result is not obscured by the possibility of a loss of energy be- tween the creation and the decay of the core-to-bound state excitation. Such an energy transfer to the sub- strate has been previously observed for other small chemisorbed molecules on meta substrates [4,5,10]. The basic mechanism for this energy transfer is the spin-flip of the excited it electron due to the degen- erate substrate electrons. The n resonance is ob- served at 534.5 eV. From the measured kinetic energy of 508.7 eV for the 2a~ orbital and the work function of the analyzer (4.5 eV), we find a discrepancy of only 0.1 eV in energy between the direct photo- emission and deexcitation. This is within the uncer- tainty of our measured values and consequently we find no observable energy shift between excitation and deexcitation for 02 on Pt (111). From a simple molecular orbital approach it has to be expected that the 2cr8 2a~ splitting decreases as the bond length of the molecule increases. The 2au3a5 splitting on the other hand exhibits the op- posite behavior and increases with an increase in Orbital 02 on Pt(1ll)~ 02 on graphite ref. [91 02 gas p ref. [7] hase ref. [S] lit8 (X2l18) 6.2 13.1 12.07 lit,, (A4fl,,) (A211,,) 5 9.5 10 12 17.0 16.7 17.7 3; (B41;) (B2~) 11.8 0.2 12 14.3 18.8 21.1 18.2 20.4 2o~ (C4E:) (C2E 21.2 0.2 18.2 20.7 25.3 27.9 24.6 27 2o~ (4E;) (2E ) 29.4 1 32.5 35 39.6 41.6 38 40 Fig. 3. Calculated differences in Koopmans theorem ionization potentials for gas-phase 02 and 0~ . The differences have been plotted relative to their values at R(0 0) = 1.208 A. The abso- lute values of the differences at this separation are: 2ag 2au 15.1 eV, 2a~ 3; 9.9 eV (neutral), and 2a8 2aa 14.5 eV, 2aa 3; 10.3 cV (dianion), bond length. The relative position of the three lowest a orbitals therefore should be a sensitive measure of the internuclear distance. The fact that these orbitals are more tightly bound than any substrate electrons makes their measurement even more reliable, since these electrons are not involved in the cheniisorp- tion bond. These trends are illustrated in fig. 3, which shows the variation with 0.-0 bond distance of the differ- ence between 3; and 2a~ Koopmans theorem (KT) ionization potentials, as well as the corresponding 2; and 2a8 difference for both (gas phase) 02 and 0~ ~ . The differences are plotted relative to the calculated values at the equilibrium gas phase (neu- tral) 0 0 distance of 1.208 A. Although the charge on the molecule has been varied over a large range in the calculations, the IP differences are seen in fig. 3 to be insensitive to the presence of negative charges. Indeed, the calculated 2a~ 3; differences for neu- tral and dianion are indistinguishable over the full ~ The ionization potentials were obtained as orbital energies from Hartree Fock calculations carried out on the 02 neutral 3E~ and (hypothetical) dianion lit ground states as a function of bond distance. Basis sets used in the calculatioi~s were a (9s, 5p 13s, 2p) contracted Gaussian set, augmented with a single set of d and diffuse p functions from ref. [Il]. > e 21 C E e o C) 4) C w C t 5.0 2.5 0.0 -2.5 -5.0 -7.5 -10.0 1.15 2 a~- 2a~ (dianion) + 1.25 1.35 - 1.45 O-O Distance (A) 1.55 1.05 Table t 02 valence ionization potentials (eV) Measured relative to E~. 563 Volume 146, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETrERS 20 May 1988 range of bond distances. Therefore it is also safe to assume that the W differences are unaffected by the difference in screening in the chemisorption com- plex compared to the isolated molecule. The isolated 02 molecule is paramagnetic with both unpaired electrons occupying lic0 orbitals in a triplet configuration. Therefore all gas phase a photo- emission peaks are split into a doublet and a quartet components. This splitting is between 2 and 2.5 eV (see table 1). The calculated values of the ionization potential in fig. 3 average over these different con- figurations. The l;-derived states of 02 chemi- sorbed on Pt (Ill) are located between 5 and 9 eV below the Fermi level of the substrate. These states are hybridized with the substrate states and ob- viously cannot contain electrons in an unpaired spin configuration. Moreover, only a single peak for each a orbital is observed for chemisorbed 02, which also shows that the 02 molecule is no longer paramag- netic. The persistence of the 02 ic~ resonance at 534.5 eV indicates that at least one level with it8 character is still accessible however. This implies that the bonding to the surface via the it8 orbital is probably not strong, and suggests that the presence of an 0~ species can be ruled out. From the measured (see table 1) splitting between the 2; and 2a0 states, we find a value of 8.2 1.2 eV for 02 on Pt (111) whereas the corresponding en- ergy difference is 12.3 eV for 02 on graphite and 13.6 eV for 02 in gas phase. From fig. 3, we see that a de- crease of this value by 5.4 1.2 eV, corresponding to the difference between the value for the free mole- cule and the species chemisorbed on Pt, indicates that the bond length is increased by 0.19 0.04 A to 1.40 0.04 A. Analogously, we determine the split- ting between the 3; and 2a11 single hole states to be 9.4 0.4 eV in 02 on Pt(1i1), 6.3 eV in 02 on graphite, and 6.6 eV in the free molecule. According to the curves in fig. 3 an increase of this splitting by 2.8 OE4 eV corresponds to a bond length change of 0.18 0.03 A from 1.21 to 1.39 0.03 A. This matches very well the value of the bond length de- termined from the 2a9 2a~ splitting and thus the two data sets are consistent. 02 is strongly electronegative and therefore one might expect that the it-hybridized orbitals, which are involved in the substrate bond, are more con- centrated around the O nuclei than in the metal sur- face. Thus the average charge in the oxygen molecule might be increased on the surface, with the increase in bond length being a consequence of this charge transfer. Incidentally, the bond length determined here by photoemission is somewhat shorter than the one determined from NEXAFS earlier (1.45 A) [2]. The bond length of 1.40 0.04 A is still substantially shorter than in singly bonded H202 (1.49 A). We have shown that the electronic structure of 02 chemisorbed on Pt (111) is consistent with a mole- cule in a ic-bonded configuration. Unlike gas phase 02, the splitting of the single hole a orbital pho- toemission final states is not observed, indicating that the 1; orbitais are hybridized with the substrate and at least partially filled. The observation of a 1 it~ res- onance, however, suggests that at least one of the chemisorptive 1 ic8 Pt (111) bonds is not strong, and that the it orbital is accessible via intramolecular ex- citation. The measured binding energy and the sep- aration between the three innermost a orbitals indicates a bond length of 1.40 0.04 A in the chemisorbed state. This corresponds to an increase of 0.19 A compared to the free molecule. This is a nice example how photoemission can be used as a tool to quantitatively determine the molecular ge- ometry of an adsorbate. In the future these studies should be extended to different diatomic molecules. We would like to thank Professor C. Kunz for stimulating discussions and one of us (WE) would like to thank the staff of Hasylab for their hospitality during his stay at Hamburg. These experiments were also supported by the BMFT under contract No. 05 305 AX B Teiiv. 3. References [1] J.L. Gland, B.A. Sexton and G.B. Fisher, Surface Sci. 95 (1980) 587. [21 J. Stohr, J.L. Baer, in: ESCA applied to free molecules (North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1969). [8] J.H.D. Eland, in: Electron spectroscopy, Vol. 3, eds. C.R. Brundle and A.D. Baker (Academic Press, New York, 1979) p. 231. [9] W. Eberhardt and E.w. Plummer, Phys. Rev. Letters 47 (1981) 1476. [10] K.?. Huber and G. Herzberg, Molecular spectra and molec- ular structure. Constants of diatomic molecules (Van Nos- trand Reinhold, New York, 1979). [11] T.H. Dunning and P.J. Hay, in: Modern theoretical chem- istry, Vol.4, ed. H.F. Schaefer III (Plenum Press, New York, 1977). 565 in gas phase. From fig. 3, we see that a de- crease of this value by 5.4 1.2 eV, corresponding to the difference between the value for the free mole- cule and the species chemisorbed on Pt, indicates that the bond length is increased by 0.19 0.04 A to 1.40 0.04 A. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We have measured the electronic structure of O2 chemisorbed in a π-bonded configuration on Pt(111) at 100 K. The positions of the inner valence levels of the adsorbate are extremely sensitive to the molecular adsorbate bond length. Comparing the measured binding energies of the three innermost σ-valence orbitals with calculations for the free O2 molecule, we deduce a bond length of 1.40±0.04 Å for the chemisorbed O2 species. This is substantially larger than the internuclear distance in the free molecule (1.21 Å). This study establishes that inner valence photoemission can be used to quantitatively determine the bond lengths for molecular adsorbates.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Molecular spectra and molecular structure. Constants of diatomic molecules
